name: Taylor, Angus MP
content: I rise to speak on Labors Fair Work Legislation Amendment (Secure Jobs, Better Pay) Bill 2022. This bill is not about consensus; its about control—and not even control by the Labor Party itself, but control by Labors union masters. At a time of growing inflation; businesses struggling with staff shortages, and weve heard about some of that from the previous speaker; rapidly increasing energy costs; and other costs of doing business, Labor and their union masters will make a difficult situation much worse. Thats exactly what this bill will do: make a difficult situation much worse.The changes proposed in this bill represent the most radical shake-up of our industrial relations system in decades. Its about creating conflicts in workplaces—conflicts that we havent seen for many years. Indeed, it was those opposite who championed enterprise bargaining, and I think that played an enormously important role in reducing some of those conflicts in the workplace by looking for opportunities, both for employers and employees, to do well together and to align their interests.But of course thats not what well see out of this. Well see legislation that will stop businesses from negotiating pay and conditions with their employees separately and independently. Instead, it will hand over control to centralised decision-makers. Thats exactly what we saw we had to move away from in the eighties. In fact, it was the Hawke government which led the way. As someone who grew up very much during that era—I was at university in that era—I thought that was a responsible and sensible government in many ways, as a Labor government. As Labor governments go, I have to say that it has to be one of the better ones Ive seen. But they did realise that it was all about getting employers and employees working together to find opportunities that were mutually beneficial.This bill, on the other hand, just like Labors recent budget that weve all forgotten already, is a missed opportunity—an absolute missed opportunity. As the Leader of the Opposition pointed out in his excellent contribution yesterday, all of us have a genuine desire to have a better industrial relations system, but thats not what were getting here. All of us have a genuine desire to see higher real wages, but theres no evidence that this bill will deliver that. In fact, from all the comments weve seen from employers, the evidence is exactly the opposite. In fact, these changes will lead, firstly, to more strikes and job losses—and we heard the previous speaker talk about that.I remember well the shearers strikes he talked about, moving from 10 combs to 13 combs. We saw, not far from here, the small town of Bowning, which used to be in my electorate—its just outside my electorate now—where, I think Im right in saying, Richard Glover was assaulted during a series of very aggressive and, sadly, occasionally violent strikes over wide combs. These were small businesses and shearers who wanted to use the wide combs because they could get through more sheep in a day and get paid more. But it didnt suit the union masters; it wasnt what they wanted. So we saw, sadly, violence in woolsheds in this region. Its something that I saw and that I learnt from. It shaped my view very much at the time. Every shearer I worked with wanted to move to enterprise bargaining to come up with a deal that worked both for them and for employers, and thats exactly what happened. It was the end of the involvement of unions in the shearing sheds. Why? Because they werent helping; they were getting in the way.This was an enormously important learning. We dont need to go back to the centralised, multi-enterprise bargaining arrangement we had back in that era, which caused so much damage and made both workers and employers worse off. That was the irony of it: the only people who were better off under that system were the union bosses—Ernie Ecob and his mates. They were the ones who were arguing for it. You remember it! The minister opposite remembers Ernie Ecob! He was better off without the wide combs, but everyone else was better off with them. Thats where you end up in a situation like this.Of course, this will allow unions into small businesses, which have never had to deal with them before. Small businesses dont have a HR department. They dont have the skills and resources that big companies have. Yet theyre going to be expected to negotiate agreements that are every bit as complex as those for a much bigger company, which may well be on exactly the same agreement. Theyll hold up real wage rises because of increased complexity and delays. Theyll undermine competition. In fact, the way it was explained by a number of those opposite was that this is all about hurting competition—thats exactly the purpose of the legislation. The Labor Party professes to believe in competition, but this is going to do the exact opposite: it will make sure that Australians have fewer choices and higher costs. It will force up the cost of living and unfairly target small businesses, because these changes will be complicated and expensive, and, as I said, small businesses simply dont have the resources to deal with them. In the era in which I grew up, I saw it time and time again: in a small business you just dont have the capacity to deal with these issues.The bill does contain changes to the BOOT, and the coalition is supportive of those changes. Well always back in changes that we think make sense, and these certainly are reforms that we welcome. I will remind this chamber that they are changes that were before the Senate 18 months ago and that the then Albanese opposition fought against them. It seems that was only for political reasons. But its good news that they are going forward, and we very much support those changes.All of this adds up, ultimately, to pressures on Australian households and businesses. We see in the budget papers just how much pressure will be on them. There were promises made that mortgages would be cheaper—that everything would be cheaper—and that real wages were going to go up. And then we got the budget. What did we see in the budget? We saw the cost of living going up: electricity bills going up by 56 per cent, gas bills going up by 44 per cent, tax payments going up. There was over $140 billion in additional taxes in this budget versus the March budget—$140 billion between March and now. Of course, bracket creep is part of that. Those opposite hate that; thats why they want to get rid of the stage 3 tax cuts! We know from the budget that employment is going to go down, but the other thing that the budget tells us is that real wages are going to go down in the term of this parliament—theyll be dropping in this parliament. Despite all the grandiose promises we heard from those opposite during the election campaign, real wages—another broken election promise—are going to go down. So the budget had no answers for cost of living, and now we have this bill, which is only going to make things worse.Business has come out very clearly about this. We heard the Prime Minister today claim that businesses are in favour of it, but it seems to me, from what they are saying, that that isnt even close to the truth. As Andrew McKellar, the chief executive of ACCI, said:The Productivity Commission has warned of a potential surge in strikes, supply chain bottlenecks, and a chain reaction of unsustainable wage claims if our workplace relations system is re-focussed towards multi-employer deals. The commissions report confirms what we knew all along: any significant move away from enterprise negotiations by rapidly expanding multi-employer agreements would pose a significant risk to jobs, to productivity, and to business.Very well put! And, of course, that puts in clear terms what I was describing earlier: the experience of those of us who lived through that era where we had these sorts of agreements in the past—that was exactly the outcome.Andrew McKellar went on to say:We must heed these concerns. Excessively broadening the scope of multi-employer agreements will lead to industry-wide strike action which we simply cannot afford.Innes Willox from the AiG said:The proposed changes to Australias workplaces introduced to federal parliament today risk taking the country down a path of more strikes, fewer jobs, centralised decision making and less trust within our enterprises.Jennifer Westacott from the Business Council said:We want wages to go up but that wont be achieved by creating more complexity, more strikes and higher unemployment.Peter Strong, the former CEO of COSBOA, said in an article of 31 October:The governments approach to the modern workplace is nothing but ideology and cronyism becoming policy.Ideology and cronyism becoming policy! Strong words but, I think, sadly, too close to the truth.And also, of course, in this bill we see the abolition of the ABCC which, in itself, will have appalling consequences for the economy. This is a bill which, as I said, isnt good policy. It is just about politics.
subdebateinfo: Fair Work Legislation Amendment (Secure Jobs, Better Pay) Bill 2022
Speaker: Mr TAYLOR (Hume)

name: Sukkar, Michael MP
content: These changes proposed in the Fair Work Legislation Amendment (Secure Jobs, Better Pay) Bill 2022 that were debating tonight represent some of the most radical changes to industrial relations that weve seen in a generation. I can say, as the former Assistant Treasurer, and from dealing with the inflationary challenges the economy is facing right now. If every member of this House and, indeed, all the senators in the other place, are speaking and listening to their respective constituents then they should be hearing the same message time and time again that I know I am when I get out into the electorate or around the country—about the cost-of-living pressures that Australians are facing. Were seeing unprecedented levels of inflation, certainly in our lifetime and were seeing huge pressures on family budgets now, with increasing interest rates—notwithstanding the fact that the Prime Minister promised cheaper mortgages before the election.From sitting down with the former Treasurer and Treasury officials before the election, if there is one thing that you would not do in an environment where youre facing these inflationary pressures and looking at the inflationary fire in front of you—the last thing you would do—its to throw fuel on the fire by taking Australias industrial relations system to where this bill seeks to take it. Its the exact opposite of what you would do if you were trying to reduce inflationary pressures in the economy.And theres no mandate for this—absolutely no mandate for this. This was not taken to the Australian people before the election. The Australian people were not given an opportunity to look at this. Indeed, in an environment where Australian small businesses suffered so greatly, particularly during the pandemic, to now be hit with this—something which the previous speaker, the shadow Treasurer, quite rightly pointed out is going to be a massive new burden on small businesses—is yet another reason for why this bill does not represent what the economy needs, does not represent what households need and does not represent what small businesses need.What weve seen in the budget are real wages continuing to decrease, and the justification for this bill is that it equates to higher wages. Wheres the economic modelling that shows that? Id be surprised if the minister, whos wedded to this bill and is very confident of his position, hasnt commissioned very detailed modelling by Treasury to show that this bill meets its explicit purpose, which is to increase wages. What I fear is going to happen is the worst of both worlds. What I fear is that the inflationary pressures that this will place on the economy not only will make inflation worse, which will therefore put more pressure on the Reserve Bank to increase interest rates, but also will lead to greater inflationary pressures by gumming up the economy. We know what multi-employer or patent bargaining will do. Weve seen it all before. This is not theoretical; we know what it will do. It will increase industrial disputation.Now, Im someone who is very supportive of union members, very supportive of people in unions organising. But I find it very difficult to ever support anything in this House that is designed not for the benefit of union members but for the benefit of the entitled elite at the top of those unions—the union leaders themselves—and the organisation. And this is what this bill reeks of. I fear that not only will we see greater inflationary pressures that will take money out of peoples pockets, which then leads to the Reserve Bank having to put interest rates up even further, taking more money out of peoples pockets, but also that it will create a workplace relations environment in this country that will see people lose their livelihoods through lost jobs and that will not see wages increase for anybody. Wheres the evidence for the assertions of those opposite? Sadly, I think there could be a trifecta of negative consequences for your average Australian, for your average worker and, indeed, for your average union member.As other speakers have quite rightly pointed out in this debate, theres only one group that we know will unequivocally benefit from this bill. Theres only one group that we can say, with almost 100 per cent certainty, will benefit from this bill, and that is the union leaders. And weve seen the union leaders come out crowing about this. It doesnt seem to be about the people they represent; it seems to be about them.Indeed, the leader of the CFMMEU, John Setka, seems to be so certain of the outcome for him and for his union organisation in this bill that he was very complimentary. He was impressed by the ministers move to scrap the ABCC and building code, which is also contained in this. Now, he doesnt give out praise too easily. In fact, John Setka has fought with his fair share of Labor members and ministers over the years. He tends to hold his praise back for exceptional circumstances. But John Setka, with a grin on his face, knows that this bill will deliver for him and for the union leadership, and I doubt he has any concern about whether it will deliver for his workers.Small businesses, after what they have gone through during the pandemic—and, yes, huge amounts of support was put in place by the former coalition government to get those businesses through—are fatigued. They are dealing with a difficult economic environment, an economic environment that, quite frankly, is deteriorating—their confidence is rapidly deteriorating. I suspect the jobs market will deteriorate. They are now going to be hit with a new set of laws that will essentially allow the foxes into the henhouse. Small business is having to cope with a union knocking on the door—and lets remember, the union leaders business model is not for industrial harmony. A union does not have a reason for existence if employers and employees are working cooperatively together. They are motivated and incentivised to go to those small businesses and try and exacerbate issues and find problems, even in areas where there may not be any. Those small businesses will now have to deal with somebody like John Setka, who will come knocking.I can tell you that small businesses owners who are fatigued—mum-and-dad small businesses owners who are working 18 hours a day to keep their business afloat, who pay their staff first, rent second, tax third and themselves last—will now have union leaders like John Setka knocking on, or bashing down, the door to shake them down even more. If the Labor Party think that you can just keep loading up small businesses and theyll just keep going no matter what burdens you load on them, I fear we are going to see consequences that will make even Labor realise, in time, what theyve done. We could have a trifecta of circumstances in which small businesses have their lives made more difficult, wages do not see any improvement, and inflationary pressures through industrial disputation feed into inflation, which therefore feeds into higher interest rates. This is almost the worst possible thing you could do in this economic environment, and, sadly, Labor did not take it to an election and were not honest before the election.
subdebateinfo: Fair Work Legislation Amendment (Secure Jobs, Better Pay) Bill 2022
Speaker: Mr SUKKAR (Deakin)

name: OBrien, Ted MP
content: Im delighted to rise this evening to speak against this bill. The name of the bill is quite confusing. They refer to this bill as the Fair Work Legislation Amendment (Secure Jobs, Better Pay) Bill 2022. It should in fact read insecure jobs and lower standard of living bill. Nevertheless, it has been the governments call as to what words to use. Many of my colleagues have already outlined some very good cases for why this bill should be opposed. Let me focus on three. Firstly, this bill represents a dirty dividend to the union movement in Australia. Secondly, it is aimed at stoking division in Australian workplaces. Thirdly, it will leave the Australian economy and Australian workers worse off—the economy weaker and workers poorer.Lets start with the dirty dividend. We have to remember that, since 2007, $100 million has gone from the union movement in Australia to the Australian Labor Party. This is a dirty dividend between the union movement and the Labor Party. I remember an image, which I believe was from 1963—a photo of Arthur Calwell and Gough Whitlam. They were only a few kilometres away from where we are now. They were outside the Kingston Hotel—the Kingo—and they were looking down, forlorn and melancholy, because inside, behind closed doors, were the puppeteers of the Labor Party: 36 unionists, who were determining the policies that the Labor politicians would take to that years federal election. Times change a little because then they called them faceless—faceless puppeteers, faceless men. Nowadays, the unions need not stay behind closed doors. They are very happy to shout out loud that they are in control of the Labor Party, and they shout it loudly as the Labor MPs in this place bow to them—unashamedly so.This is a dirty dividend, and we know it is when you have the likes of John Setka saying, as he has with regard to this legislation, We will have the power to go after non-union sites. Can I underscore that word power. This is precisely why the likes of John Setka are happy. Why wouldnt the CFMMEU be happy? They currently have around 30 representatives in front of the courts. Since we re-established the Registered Organisations Commission and the ABCC, the Australian Building and Construction Commission, we have seen over 1,600 contraventions by the CFMMEU. Theyve had to pay out penalties of over $17 million.Is it any wonder that the unions are delighted about this piece of legislation? It is a piece of legislation that, on the other side, has united all other major parts of the Australian economy—businesses of all shapes and sizes, many of whom rarely unite. But they are absolutely united on this one, because they know this is a dirty dividend for the unions of Australia, a deal between the Australian Labor Party and the Australian union movement. Its a dirty dividend and nothing more. But its also, by its very nature, a piece of legislation that seeks to stoke division within Australia, almost trying to bring back that notion of class struggle between capital and labour.You might recall only a couple of years ago, in the midst of the pandemic, the then coalition introduced JobKeeper, something that employers and employees across the country praised enormously. JobKeeper, at a time of crisis, was all about keeping employers and employees together, keeping them close together. This piece of legislation seeks to sever that relationship in half. This legislation seeks to divide employers from employees. This legislation is an ideological piece of work that not only delivers that dirty dividend to the union movement but stokes conflict within the workplace. We know that the multi-employer bargaining, especially, will increase the risk of widespread strikes, strike action.Theres a good reason why all representatives of the small business community are screaming about this piece of legislation. Not only does this welcome unions into workplaces where employers and employees have never needed them but it takes business owners and small operations away from their core business at a time when they can afford it least. This legislation will force them to go and have to negotiate, bargain, with other employers so they can come to some form of joint agreement, and if they do not have time to do that—and most small and medium businesses do not have the time to do that; they do not have the in-house expertise to do that—then they will stand by whatever terms and conditions other employers negotiate on their behalf. Thats what theyve got in this legislation. And, ultimately, this leaves the Australian economy weaker and the Australian people poorer.In a high-inflation environment, where we have rising interest rates, where we have low unemployment, what we really need in this country is a boost in productivity. It is no surprise that the governments budget papers downgraded its assumption about growth in productivity. While I support lowering the assumption of productivity growth to 1.2 per cent, I think that, with pieces of legislation like this, this government has Buckleys chance of reaching even that. Madam Deputy Speaker, look at total factor productivity and its two core parts, labour and capital: both need boosting in this country; both will be adversely impacted by this legislation. We know that, due to mass strikes and conflict in the workplace, we will have less output from the input of labour and less output from the use of machines and equipment through capital. We are a nation that imports investment—imports money. We are a net importer of capital. This does nothing to attract new investment. Overall, therefore, it will be a killer of productivity. Anyone who has learnt any economics or who has ever lived in the real-world economy understands that the main driver of the standard of living is productivity, yet this bill kills productivity.In summary, this piece of legislation represents a dirty dividend from the Australian Labor Party to the Australian union movement. It is aimed at stoking division in the workplace. It will leave the Australian economy weaker and, ultimately, the Australian people poorer. Its a return to the bad old days of the seventies and it should be absolutely rejected.
subdebateinfo: Fair Work Legislation Amendment (Secure Jobs, Better Pay) Bill 2022
Speaker: Mr TED OBRIEN (Fairfax)

name: Pearce, Gavin MP
content: I understand completely the lack of interest that some of the public—most of the public—down our way display when they hear words and phrases like political parties, politicians, industrial relations and legislation. Their eyes glaze over. Most would rather be cleaning their toaster or vacuuming their cat. I get that—I completely get that. But this is a defining moment. This is the biggest, most radical change in IR legislation that weve seen in generations. All Australians—whether you have a job, whether youre looking for a job or whether youre a business owner—should be tuning in and taking notice, because this bill will affect every single worker, job and workplace right across the nation. There is little doubt that, if you believe in aspiration and the capacity of the individual, in personal choice and personal responsibility, the Fair Work Legislation Amendment (Secure Jobs, Better Pay) Bill 2022 isnt the bill for you; in fact, it is a giant step backwards for our workers and our workplaces.Everyone in this place wants Australian workers to have good, safe, well-paid jobs, to get a fair days pay for a fair days work—and thats fair enough. We want them to be appropriately remunerated for the skills they bring to the workplace and to receive a pay packet that allows them to save, to prosper and to get ahead in life. We want our great local businesses to be profitable so that they can employ those same people who are trying to get ahead in life. Unfortunately, this legislation will not deliver on these noble aspirations that we all agree on, these things we want for the people of our respective electorates. What this bill does is to take away the very gains weve made in our workplaces and businesses over many decades. It takes us all back to the dirty old days of the seventies. It goes back to a time when previous Labor governments sold their souls to their union masters. We all knew that this was coming; we just didnt think it would come so quickly and be slipped under the carpet the way it has been.We all know that the unions are major contributors to the Australian Labor Party. In fact, as has been mentioned many times, since 2007 over a hundred million dollars has been donated to the Labor Party. But this generosity is not given for free; it comes at a price. This bill is the price the Albanese government is going to have to pay in order to get that support or receive those funds. It will be a hefty price that we will pay as a small business community as we see this bill form legislation.I dont need to tell people across my electorate that things are difficult. Inflation is going up, mortgages are going up, businesses are struggling to get staff, fuel costs are going up, fertiliser prices are through the roof, and it all looks like its going to get worse before it gets better. The cost of doing business is increasing rapidly. What this bill will do is make the situation worse. The bill will delay much-needed wage rises because of the added layer of complexity to the system. It will undermine competition and force up prices. It will lead to more strikes, more job losses and more industrial unrest.In spite of what we are hearing from those on the other side, governments dont create jobs. It is our enterprising small business sector and our employers that create jobs. Governments role is to place the frameworks and the supports around those small businesses so they can grow more jobs. Governments should provide the tools and the levers that allow businesses and employers—and employees, for that matter—to grow and prosper, creating more jobs. Thats not this bill. This bill will lead to more strikes and more job losses. And its not me thats saying that; its the employers and the employer lobby groups right across the nation that have made their point very clear. What the other side needs to do is listen.I come from the great state of Tasmania, and we are of course an island state. Everything that comes in and out of that state comes by air or by sea. The electorate of Braddon is home to Tasmanias largest port, the port of Burnie, importing and exporting approximately five million tonnes of containerised and bulk minerals freight. Just up the road, again in Braddon, is the port of Devonport, 3.7 million tonnes. When you combine the Devonport port with the Burnie port, that provides 94.6 per cent of Tasmanias containerised and bulk mineral freight in and out of the state. Its there that we see industrial action at its best—or at its worst, in this case.Its coming up to Christmas time, and its about that time that unions generally flex their muscles, puff their chest out and decide to go slow in the port of Melbourne or Port Botany or wherever else that ship is coming from. What that effectively does—and Ive lived through this from the business end; this is what I have seen from being an agricultural operator in north-west Tasmania—is it absolutely puts a chokehold on the great state of Tasmania. Businesses go broke, cows dont get fed, canola doesnt come in, protein doesnt come in, raw products dont come in. They dont come in for our advanced manufacturers. We dont see those products going out to the Melbourne and Sydney markets either. It stifles growth. It cripples businesses and it hurts employees. It hurts the very people that these unions are supposed to be helping.Its for frivolous reasons. I went through a go-slow process with the maritime union out at port of Melbourne over air conditioning not working on a forklift. That went for a week. That went for a week and it cost people jobs, it cost farmers money, and people were subsequently laid off. These werent big operators. This is not big business. These are mum-and-dad businesses, sole traders or partnerships where mum and dad are the operation staff who do the hiring and firing and pay the people. But when mum and dad have to deal with green or red tape or, in this case, industrial relations, that means 50 per cent of that business has stopped being effective. That means that 50 per cent of that business has got to take their eyes off the road and deal with this complex legislation. Normally, big businesses would have a specialised department or an office that would deal with such legislation. This is going to hurt the small operators, the small businesses, and thats what this country is built on.Coming from small business myself, I understand completely. I would say that 99.9 per cent of the small businesses out there in Australia care deeply about their employees. They understand that the most valuable asset for any small business is their staff. I know I wouldnt have had a business, and it certainly wouldnt have been successful, if it werent for the good team of people that I had. I went without to make sure they were paid each fortnight. I had a business that didnt gain revenue during the winter months, so Id save money during the summer months so that I could keep my people on, so they could have a job to go to, so they could look after their families. At Christmas time, I would kill cattle and give them a whole beast so that they could feed their families. All these things arent talked about; all these things arent documented; all these things dont appear on the ABC or in other outlets. But I tell you what: there are a lot of businesses out there doing the absolute right thing by their people, and that should be recognised in here tonight.This bill certainly doesnt do that. It certainly rubs, as far as Im concerned, salt into the wounds of small businesses who are just trying to do the right thing. All they want is a fair go. I think we need to recognise that we would no sooner hurt our people or take away from our employees than we would hurt our own children, and I mean that so sincerely. We need to get out of this big-city mentality, where we have workers that work for five levels of bosses, and start thinking about the mum-and-dad businesses that this is going to hurt, and its serious business.In closing, I guess you can glean from my tone and from the points that Ive raised that I am not happy with this bill and nor are my small business operators in the great state of Tasmania. We want a future. We want a future for our businesses. We want a future for their prosperity. But, more importantly, we want businesses who look after their employees, and thats where we need to get back to—that is, small business and looking after our people. This bill does none of that.
subdebateinfo: Fair Work Legislation Amendment (Secure Jobs, Better Pay) Bill 2022
Speaker: Mr PEARCE (Braddon)

name: Coleman, David MP
content: Lets be frank: the Fair Work Legislation Amendment (Secure Jobs, Better Pay) Bill 2022 is a grotesque piece of legislation. Nothing like this has been introduced into this parliament for decades. Its not about more wages; its about more union members. Of course unions have a legitimate role to play in our economy, and if people choose to join a union that is absolutely their right. But this legislation takes the really critical issue of wages and uses that as a stalking horse to radically increase unionisation in the workforce. Thats what this is about. Its not about wages. Wages is the headline; unionisation is the substance. And I will come to how that works in a little bit more detail soon. So its not pro wage growth. Its not pro worker. Its not those things. It is definitely pro union.Its also unashamedly antibusiness. You would think that in recent decades we would have moved beyond the old Australia of a very us and them attitude between business and unions. Indeed, the governments of Australia, at least for the last 40 years, have tended to take a fairly constructive approach to these sorts of matters and have tended to support policies that seek to bring everyone together. But thats not what this does, because this is a piece of legislation which is deliberately hostile to Australian business. And thats a very sad day for this parliament, because, if were not supporting Australian business, were not encouraging the growth that we all need in order to employ people and in order for Australians to have jobs that enable them to pursue their dreams. Its a very hostile piece of legislation.Imagine if the current government had said before the election: You know what were going to do? Were going to introduce a really radical piece of industrial relations legislation soon after the election. Itll be one of the first things we do after the budget. I suspect that would not have had a very good reaction. At a bare minimum it would have prompted a lot of questions. What is this particularly radical piece of industrial relations legislation going to introduce? Understandably, thats what people would have asked. But thats not what the government said before the election. When David Speers asked the now Treasurer whether industry-wide bargaining was something the then opposition Labor Party was looking at, the then shadow Treasurer said, Its not part of our policy. That is a very black-and-white statement.So theres no mandate for this. There is no mandate to introduce it at all. Theres certainly no mandate to seek to rush it through the parliament, and it goes to integrity, something weve heard a lot about in recent years. Lets talk about integrity, because—I dont know, maybe Im naive—I would have thought, if youre going to radically change Australias industrial relations landscape and you want to do so with integrity, youd tell people about it before the election. That would seem to be an act of integrity. Not telling them about it—in fact, explicitly telling them that youre not going to do it—would seem to be entirely lacking in integrity. So we should reflect on integrity. This is not the only issue on which the governments integrity has been sadly lacking, but this is a particularly clear-cut example. What governments with integrity introduce radical change after saying they wont do so? They dont, because, if they had integrity, they wouldnt do it.Weve got to get to the substance of this legislation. What is the problem the legislation is trying to solve? The problem the legislation is trying to solve is declining union membership. This is a big problem for the government because its a big problem for the unions. Declining union membership is bad for the unions; bad for unions equals bad for government. So the question for unions is: How are we going to fix that? It is a significant problem for the unions because the level of union membership has declined substantially, from 46 per cent in 1986—not long ago—to 14 per cent in the most recent ABS figures. In the private sector, less than 10 per cent of Australians are now members of unions, so in the private sector there are more left-handers than there are union members. I can say this as someone with lived experience as a left-hander. There are more left-handers than union members. Thats a huge problem for unions—an existential threat. That means that this government must introduce policy that forces up the rate of union membership.What this legislation seeks to do is give the unions a marketing tool to bring more people into the movement. That marketing tool is a false promise of higher wages, which isnt going to happen because this legislation isnt going to lead to that at all. But the false promise of higher wages is on the back of a new and far-reaching capacity to strike and to shut businesses down through strikes. This legislation is pretty simple at its core. It will force businesses to participate in bargaining processes that have absolutely nothing to do with their business. And if they dont agree to the union demand in that process, bearing in mind that the demand probably has nothing at all to do with their business, the legislation provides for very broad rights to strike and effectively shut down that business. That, as well come to, goes right across the country.You can have a business in Bruny and a business in Bundaberg, and today theyre following the relevant award, as theyre required to do. But, under this law, all that needs to happen in order for the business in Bruny to be roped into a Bundaberg dispute is that theres some sort of dispute in Bundaberg. If the majority of employees in Bruny, who could be casuals who work three or four hours per week, say, Yes wed like to get involved in that dispute, the business in Bruny then gets dragged into a dispute in Bundaberg. Youd say, Surely that could only happen if those businesses had some really tight connection. But thats not the case because the legislation states that they should have a common interest. But the term common interest is so broad as to be completely meaningless.It could be businesses which are thousands of kilometres apart or, alternatively, it could be businesses whose common interest is merely their geographic location, which is completely absurd. Just because two businesses are in Shepparton, thats their common interest, so lets rope them into the same dispute. Its absolutely absurd, so where does it go? Where does it lead? It leads to a situation where it is very easy to rope businesses into these disputes. A set of demands is put, and, if businesses dont agree to those demands, theyre easily roped into the dispute through these provisions, and then strike action ensues. That is what is going to happen. Its crystal clear, and its very similar to where we were in the seventies. To the credit of the Hawke government, they got rid of that system, but this is what this system seeks to reintroduce. It is a chaotic scenario.It was good to see that some of the employer representatives went along to the so-called jobs summit, which of course was going to be a wonderful national conversation about the great promise of Australia. But the only thing that came out of the jobs summit was this. You will recall Sally McManus saying we should have industry-wide pattern bargaining. You will recall the government saying, Maybe thats a good idea. And you will recall that, a couple of weeks later, very detailed legislation was produced. So the jobs summit was an absolute stitch-up from the start.Its good to see that the industry associations—perhaps some of them were a little naive, one might say, in some of their earlier conduct—have really strongly come out against this legislation because it is so bad for Australian businesses, so bad for Australian jobs. Andrew McKellar from ACCI has been particularly forthright in his comments, noting that it was a seismic shift to Australias workplace relations and would result in more strikes, fewer jobs, centralised decision-making and less trust within our enterprises. So the kumbaya moments of the jobs summit sadly didnt last, because this is the real intent of this government.Motivation is a good point on which to finish. Thats what this legislation goes to—motivation. The motivation isnt about wages. It isnt about workers. It isnt about the economy. Its about giving the unions a tool to drive union membership, because today, in the private sector, there are more left-handers than there are union members. The union movement need to change that. They put this legislation on the table. The government has enthusiastically adopted it. Its a very bad day for the country, and this legislation should be vigorously opposed.
subdebateinfo: Fair Work Legislation Amendment (Secure Jobs, Better Pay) Bill 2022
Speaker: Mr COLEMAN (Banks)

name: Buchholz, Scott MP
content: For the benefit of those who are listening on the broadcast, can I just give you an overview of the parliament as it sits at the moment. Its just gone nine oclock, and the room has seven opposition members here ready to prosecute this debate. The chamber is empty on the other side. But those that are here need affirmation, and particular affirmation goes to the Leader of the House, the member who brought the bill, the Fair Work Legislation Amendment (Secure Jobs, Better Pay) Bill 2022, before the House. A little-known fun fact is that 85 per cent of legislation that comes before the House—at least in the last five terms that Ive had the privilege of serving here, a period of 10 years—goes through uncontested. Its the last 15 per cent that we really muscle up on. And industrial relations is one of the areas that we will sink our teeth into.For the benefit, again, of those who are listening on the broadcast, what happens is that both sides of the House are given their speaking points, and theyre sent in to deliver their sides speaking points. You will not get that from me. My speaking points have been put to the side. I just want to say that there is not anyone in Australia who doesnt look forward to a pay rise. Everyone is looking for a pay rise. The government mentioned before the election that they would do it. As they should, they have honoured their commitment to bring that before the House and debate it. The numbers in the House are favourable for the government, so we have respected the debate. There will be a lot of Australians who are expecting a pay rise. In saying that, I want to remind Australians that a good, effective oppositions role is to keep government accountable. Thats what the job of opposition is. Its to make sure that we keep integrity in this House and remind the Australian public of any unintended consequences that could come.No-one in Australia would question that, when we left office, our economy was strong—one of the strongest in the OECD. We had the lowest unemployment rate in history. The figure started with a 3. We had the highest female participation rate in history. Since those on the other side of the chamber came into office, the interest rate, the cash rate, has shifted 2.5 basis points. So what that means in real terms is that, if you have a mortgage of around $700,000, your payments have gone up $1,200 a month.I used to have a transport business and my payroll each week was about $80,000. That was 20 years ago. Every week I used to pay $80,000 out in wages. I suggest that from the legislation that comes before the House today, while it is a governments privilege to bring it, there will be unintended consequences. In my situation, if there were an increase of whatever the percentage might be, I would still only have $80,000 to make my wages contribution. So, if I have 100-odd staff, I will not be in a position to go to the bank every week and borrow more money to make up that difference. The effect of what happens is that I will actually say, Staff, we need to be smarter; 10 of you have to go because I only have $80,000 to make my wages contribution. The reason I mentioned that our unemployment rate started with a 3 is that I say to those on the other side of the House: while you can celebrate the victory and get intoxicated on the euphoria of those who will get the pay rise, it has to come from somewhere, and small business will have to pay it.I also want to make particular point about the amendment that was put forward by our leader. He said when moving the amendments that he wants to work with the crossbench—the crossbenchers have little or no support for this—to try and find a better deal.In conclusion, those on the other side of the House must remember: when they run out of their money, they are going to come looking for yours. (Time expired)
subdebateinfo: Fair Work Legislation Amendment (Secure Jobs, Better Pay) Bill 2022
Speaker: Mr BUCHHOLZ (Wright)

name: Conaghan, Pat MP
content: Earlier in the evening, the member for Parkes, who just left the chamber, made a wonderful contribution, but there was part of it that I took some objection to. He referred to a passage of the Bible—Luke 23: 34—where it says: Father, forgive them, for they know not what they do. I take objection to that because they know exactly what they are doing. Labor know exactly the consequences of the Fair Work Legislation Amendment (Secure Jobs, Better Pay) Bill 2022and exactly what it means for the unions. I will not mince my words; let others call this bill for what it really is. We should rename it the kickback for the unions donation bill. They are saying secure jobs, better pay, but for many businesses, particularly smaller businesses and medium-size businesses specifically in the regions, the knock-on effects from this kind of legislation will be not only detrimental but potentially devastating to them.The concept of legislating multibusiness enterprise bargaining, in my view and in the opinion of many of the businesses in my electorate, is simply lunacy. Empowering the unions in this way will completely unfairly impact regional businesses more than their metro counterparts. In my electorate, where we have rapidly growing regional businesses, it is literally our job to protect those businesses from the consequences that will flow from this bill.The vast majority of employees in my electorate are small businesses—mums and dads, family businesses—and they are the lifeblood of our community. They are the reason our communities survive. This government wants to impose this multibusiness enterprise bargaining on them. It will crush them, and I have been told that. These are not businesses with sophisticated HR or legal departments or highly trained administrators. What this bill is seeking to do is invite a union Goliath into their kitchen, to sit at the kitchen table and expect them to be able to effectively negotiate in the best interest of their own employees and their own businesses. It will crush them.The businesspeople in my electorate say to me that this bill is inviting unnecessary complexity and costly legal actions, and reducing the likelihood of individuals to take a punt and start a new business. Why would you? Why would you, when you have the unions sitting over you like a vulture, ready to pick your carcass? With the greatest respect, how is reducing the incentive to start and grow a business good for employment? How is increasing the likelihood of strike action, delays on wage rises due to union argy-bargy and, ultimately, the undermining of competition going to secure jobs? How is it going to secure jobs? There will be fewer jobs. There will be more strikes and fewer jobs. If it crushes businesses, the business will fold, or a business owner will say: Im not going to deal with this. Im not going to go into this bargaining process. I will just lay people off. I will lay workers off. That is exactly what is going to happen. If this bill passes, the government should pump AC/DC through the speakers of Parliament House, and play loudly, Dirty Deeds Done Dirt Cheap, because that is exactly what they have done with the unions.
subdebateinfo: Fair Work Legislation Amendment (Secure Jobs, Better Pay) Bill 2022
Speaker: Mr CONAGHAN (Cowper)

name: Joyce, Barnaby MP
content: I rise to speak to the Fair Work Legislation Amendment (Secure Jobs, Better Pay) Bill 2022. One of the core principles I always believed the National Party had, and which I espouse, is the right of the individual, no matter where they were born, whether they werent born of great wealth or of great education or had the grace of a family support structure, to nonetheless transcend through the economic and social stratification of life to the highest level, limited only by their innate abilities. That means, quite obviously, that a fool will go to a fools level, a hard worker will go to a hard workers level, and an enterprising person with nous can go to the level of prosperity and freedom that their talents will allow them to rise to. Ultimately, this means that the way people—who are not trained to be solicitors, who have not been to a university or who have not been trained to be accountants, like I was, but who have been basically trained to work for another big business—transcend through that economic and social stratification of life is overwhelmingly through small business.Small business, by its very nature, relies on people working in a collegiate way with their workers. Im still involved in a small business. We do not see ourselves as the boss. We see ourselves as having the ultimate say in where things go, but we work hand in glove with those around us. We work in a collegiate way. We dont have industrial problems. We work, but we dont have industrial problems. But what is so insidious about this bill is it implies that by reason of someone elses problem it apparently also becomes my problem. It brings militancy into my workplace, and by so doing it is a disincentive for me to employ people. When you talk about a head count of 15 people, the first thing small businesses are going to think is, Lets make sure we dont break that level. We dont want a union official who weve never met and have no association with coming around to the crib room, the smoko room, out into the paddock or into the shearing shed to tell us, in a working relationship which is harmonious, that we have a problem. Because we dont have a problem.The other thing is that the most treasured possession we have is our workers. The greatest concern we have is them leaving. And they do leave. They go other places to get paid more money because there is a greater requirement for work then there are workers. I might say that, overwhelmingly, a legacy of the coalition government is record unemployment levels.We knew on the advent of a Labor government that ultimately they would go back to their true colours in quick form. We see the Labor Party having their jollies and handing over our sovereignties at the resort town of Sharm El-Sheikh in Egypt, for the great god Gaia and chasing the climate vote. Theyre telling us that they will soon be handing over wealth to other countries hell west and crooked, because apparently its a moral thing to do. Whilst that is happening overseas, they had to come back home and pay their union masters.Only about 15 per cent of Australians are union members, and overwhelmingly they are in government jobs. Do you know why? Because the rest of Australia has moved on. Theyve moved on because they can work things out for themselves in a collegiate way. If you go into regional towns and cities, there are no nests of vipers and no people militantly walking over the top of people and exploiting them. It is people making their own way.When I was an accountant I would ask people, What are your kids going to do? If they said they were going to go to uni, I would say: Why? Why would you? If you want to make money, get a trade, have a business or get a job in a business that will actually take you somewhere. Do you know what they did? They became electricians, brickies and plasterers and made a buck—more money than if they had gone to uni, got an arts degree and worked for the National Australia Bank. But once more this says: No. The only thing you can be under a Labor government is ultimately a servant.
subdebateinfo: Fair Work Legislation Amendment (Secure Jobs, Better Pay) Bill 2022
Speaker: Mr JOYCE (New England)

name: Gillespie, David MP
content: The Fair Work Legislation Amendment (Secure Jobs, Better Pay) Bill 2022 is a radical shake-up of the industrial system. There are no two ways about it. It is designed to favour unions and give them more influence, because their influence has shrunk. Their membership is down to 10 to 11 per cent. In my area, with over 3,200 small businesses, I would say that its probably way lower than that.I remember in high school in the 1970s having regular strikes. Transport and petrol strikes would always happen before school holidays, and airlines would strike—you name it. There were sectorwide strikes, and were going back to that. This current government is no Bob Hawke or Keating reforming government; this is Whitlam 2.0. What goes around comes around. Three years is a very short time. I can already see some of the little bolts on this governments wheels starting to loosen. No wheels have fallen off, but you mark my words that people are very worried about this. They know that the removal of the Australian Building and Construction Commission and the Registered Organisations Commission has been done before, and building costs went up 30 per cent because of strike action. When the ABCC was reinstituted, strikes went down by 90 per cent, so were not making it up. A lot of the provisions will create a totally different paradigm.To be able to use the common interest test willy-nilly and start sectorwide bargaining will mean much more bargaining. If people currently want to go to arbitration, they have to prove the majority of employees want to do it. But that is swept away with these changes. Its not really bargaining anymore. It is just compulsory.What small business can afford to get someone to represent them in a Fair Work Commission hearing when there are no costs awarded if you lose? In normal court actions, there is that hanging over anyone who takes action—if you lose, you have to pay the bills of the other side. But you can take anyone to the Fair Work Commission and you dont have that hanging over you. There will be heaps of cases. The Fair Work Commission will need a whole new building full of courts because this is going to be a free-for-all. Then, through these changes, they can get into businesses that have un-unionised labour. Thats why only 10 per cent of Australia are in the unions; its only the public sector of the economy that has high union membership. So, theres not a lot that I can see in this that is very encouraging.What will happen is that small numbers of disgruntled employees will be able to ring up the union, the union will be able to come and initiate it, and off we go. Then, people will buckle, because they dont want to be caught up with huge legal fees trying to defend the way theyve organised the arrangements in their business. Ive been on both sides of it. Ill happily declare that I was a member of a union for many years, when I was a salaried medical practitioner. And the AMA looked after us. Back in the day when salaried doctors careers depended on going up through the hospitals, you had to have someone on your side.But this is a different kettle of fish altogether. This is totally different. It is just open slather for thuggish unions, like the CFMMEU, whove got $16 million in fines racked up already and 30 people before the courts under charges, to be back to business as usual, using intimidation to get their way and force extra costs on good, functioning, stable businesses with happy workforces. They will then be able to get rid of a lot of small businesses. Big unions love big business, because the two go together, and that is the whole aim of this. Its a rare unionised workforce that you find in regional Australia, but its going to change radically. Sentiment towards this government will change rapidly as well.
subdebateinfo: Fair Work Legislation Amendment (Secure Jobs, Better Pay) Bill 2022
Speaker: Dr GIL LESPIE (Lyne)

name: Haines, Helen MP
content: The Fair Work Legislation Amendment (Secure Jobs, Better Pay) Bill 2022 aims to do two important things: increase wages and address gender inequality. I support these two goals. I support the important provisions of the bill that aim to increase wages, such as changes to the supported low-paid bargaining stream and simplification of the better off overall test. I also support the provisions that target gender inequality in the workplace, such as adding gender equity as an object of the Fair Work Act, the abolishment of pay secrecy clauses that would increase transparency, and the establishment of expert panels.I understand that there are problems in our employment system that we need to fix. I understand the governments intention to get wages moving. I applaud it. The issues of wage stagnation are complex. This bill is complex. The bill its amending is complex. It is worthy of detailed and diligent scrutiny. The job of a conscientious legislator is to do that scrutiny, to understand what questions need to be asked to safeguard for unintended consequences. In my mind, the speed at which the government has progressed this bill does not do justice to the very serious intent of the problem this legislation is seeking to solve.If I am to support this bill I need to return to my electorate and justify my support. I need to explain to my constituents how this bill will impact them. As the bill currently stands, I cannot do this. Im concerned about the bills changes to the multi-employer stream. I note the safeguards in the bill that aim to mitigate the possibility of businesses being forced into agreements that are not good for their business model. But there is genuine concern about this. What I cannot tell my constituents right now with absolute confidence is that they have nothing to fear—and dear God, I hate the fearmongering. I am concerned that these new measures will have unintended consequences for small businesses and ultimately for workers. Im thinking about the small and medium-size hospitality and manufacturing businesses in Wodonga, Wangaratta, Mansfield and Benalla. These businesses are grappling with the challenges of operating post COVID-19 lockdowns, border closures, rising energy costs, floods, and years of getting no skilled migration into their workforce.The proposed single-interest test stream is so complex that it may take months for businesses like these to navigate it, and still we might not see the much-needed wages increase. But I want to be clear here. I do not oppose the rights of employees to unionise and bargain with their employers for better wages and better conditions. Ive been a member of the Australian Nursing and Midwifery Federation for 43 years—Id argue that maybe longer than any other person in the House have I been a member of that union. Through my many years working as a nurse and a midwife I personally experienced how hard it can be to fight for fair pay and conditions. I lived through the 1980s nurses strikes.In the two weeks since the introduction of this bill I have consulted with the government, with peak bodies representing both employees and employers and with business groups as best I could in my electorate. Many, including COSBOA, have told me they simply do not yet understand how this bill will impact their stakeholders. The Senate committee that was hastily put together to examine this bill has not even reported back, and were expected to vote on this bill. This government has shown that it can consult on bills well. Its done so with the Climate Change Bill and the National Anti-Corruption Commission Bill. Members of this House have shown that they can work with the government in return to assist in delivering on much-needed reform. When it comes to the National Anti-Corruption Commission I can say we have moved heaven and earth to assist the government to get that work done.There are many reasons I would like to vote in favour of this bill, but I cannot at this time. I dont know if the government is done with its amendments, and I genuinely hope it works constructively with the Senate and that it may come back to this place in a form that I could support. While that debate is happening, I will do all I can to engage in good faith with the people most affected by it. If this bill passes in its entirety, it will still take months, potentially longer, for Australians to see an improvement in wages. If it is going to take that long, then why are we proceeding with such haste, when a couple more weeks to properly consider and consult on this bill will cause no material impairment? I want wages to increase, particularly for women; I want more people working; and I want our businesses to succeed, but for me this isnt the way to proceed on that.
subdebateinfo: Fair Work Legislation Amendment (Secure Jobs, Better Pay) Bill 2022
Speaker: Dr HAINES (Indi)

name: Hastie, Andrew MP
content: Australian families and businesses are struggling right now. The cost of living is rising very fast. Power prices are on the rise. Treasury has assumed that retail electricity prices will rise by 50 per cent over the next two years. Retail gas prices are up some 40 per cent this year and the next. Rising inflation is eating into the purchasing power of the average Australian family. The cost of groceries is going up. In my state of Western Australia, milk has gone up 10 per cent, oil and fats up 7.7 per cent, fruits and vegetables up 5.4 per cent, cheese up 4.6 per cent, and seafood and cereals up 4.2 per cent. School fees are going up. Sporting costs are going up. Everything is becoming more expensive for Australian families.Small businesses are doing it tough as well. They were hammered by the pandemic, and now, just as we have commenced our recovery, all their inputs are becoming more expensive. Its tough for them to get workers, particularly in WA, and even tougher getting product to market. Just ask the fruit growers that I represent in the hills region of Perth. This year they will produce some of the most expensive apples, pears and stone fruit on record. They use gas, petrol and diesel for their equipment. They use fertiliser, which has skyrocketed in cost. They rely upon transient labour. Its very hard to get fruit pickers in this job market, as the member for OConnor well knows, representing a massive agricultural electorate himself. Many are worried about the long-term prospects for their business and their families, but they are patriots, they love this country, and theyre worried about Australias food security. It was great to meet with them a few weeks ago and talk all these issues through.That is the backdrop to this IR bill, the Fair Work Legislation Amendment (Secure Jobs, Better Pay) Bill 2022, that the Albanese government is bringing before the House. The point I want to make tonight is that small business, the engine room of the Australian economy, is doing it very tough at the moment.What does this industrial relations legislation do? It makes a situation thats already very, very bad much, much worse. It becomes even tougher for small businesses. This, very simply, is a move to collectivise and unionise the small business workforce, to strip small and family businesses of their protection from lawfare and aggressive union tactics. This legislation favours big corporates and unions. Small businesses dont have the money, the time, the people or the human resources to deal with the legal complexity and exposure to industrial action this legislation will bring.This is a return to the past. This will kill off enterprise bargaining. It will bring back centralised wage fixation where wages will be fixed by the unions or the Fair Work Commission. Corporates and unions will work together to negotiate large multi-employer agreements, forcing small family businesses into agreements that will hurt their bottom line, their productivity and their ability to adapt to changing economic circumstances. We believe small businesses are the engine room of the Australian economy—places of creativity, risk taking and entrepreneurial flair—and this IR bill strikes a blow at the very heart of Australian small businesses. This legislation is about crushing the little guy, the small family business. Its a transfer of power from small business to unions and corporates. You can talk about wage increases and fairness, but there is no evidence that reverting to an antiquated IR system of this sort of bargaining will do that.I just want to put on record some significant voices in the business community whove spoken this subject. Innes Willox says:The high-risk proposals as they currently stand will create enormous difficulties for business and carry unintended consequences that will cost jobs and cause serious damage to our economy.The Business Council of Australia has stated:Australians deserve a system that delivers higher wages and better jobs, with diverse businesses that can innovate, deliver the best services and products and grow the economy.This will not achieve those outcomes, instead we are staring down the barrel of a more complex system that runs the risk of stifling innovation and fossilising the economy.Finally, Peter Strong, the former CEO of COSBOA, wrote, in an article in SmartCompany on October 31 last month:The governments approach to the modern workplace is nothing but ideology and cronyism becoming policy. This has been highlighted very well by the peak employer bodies—AIG, BCA and ACCI. The legislation is a trojan horse … for the empowerment of unions in every workplace in Australia.This is rushed, its bad policy, and we oppose it.
subdebateinfo: Fair Work Legislation Amendment (Secure Jobs, Better Pay) Bill 2022
Speaker: Mr HAS TIE (Canning)

name: Violi, Aaron MP
content: This government is rushing through this legislation and gagging debate by not allowing a proper committee to review this bill. The Fair Work Legislation Amendment (Secure Jobs, Better Pay) Bill 2022 is significant and complex. Its over 249 pages long, and its not possible to carefully consider it in the weeks time frame that Labor is demanding. The fact is this legislation will have real-world impacts on business, big and small, on employees and on the economy. It is a bill that we cannot afford to rush through. The member for Fisher reminded me of a great old saying yesterday: we should measure twice and cut once, because unintended consequences and second-order consequences are real and significant, particularly in relation to industrial relations. So we should not rush this through. We should take the time to understand the impacts of this bill.The government claim they have taken a consensus driven approach to this bill, but this is clearly not the case. The minister for workplace relations was in here today in question time talking about how theyve consulted, and he mentioned the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry and the Business Council of Australia. However, what he did not expand on was what they actually said about this bill in that consultation. Andrew McKellar from the ACCI warned that this legislation would lead to more strikes, fewer jobs, centralised decision-making and less trust within our enterprises. The BCA and the Australian Industry Group have also raised their concerns about the dangers of limited debate and scrutiny. The Business Council said:Australians deserve a system that delivers higher wages and better jobs, with diverse businesses that can innovate, deliver the best services and products and grow the economy … instead we are staring down the barrel of a more complex system that runs the risk of stifling innovation and fossilising the economy.It is clear that the Prime Ministers jobs summit was pure politics—a sham to give the facade of consensus while ramming through their union agenda.Most at risk in this legislation are small businesses. When Im visiting local businesses in Casey, their anxiety about the future is palpable. Small and family businesses are desperately worried about whether they will be able to continue to operate, let alone deal with union strikes. Almost half of my constituents in Casey—about 47,000 people—work in small business. Small business truly is the heart and soul of the economy and the community in Casey, as it is throughout the nation. At a time of growing inflation, business is struggling with staff shortages and rapidly increasing power costs. Labor and their union friends will make a bad situation into a crisis. Many small-business owners that I speak to say that there will not be any jobs to strike for if the government does not recognise the immense pressure small-business owners are already under.The reality is that this government does not understand, or care for, small business. The Prime Minister has no understanding of small business. He went straight from university to being a staffer, then a unionist and then a parliamentarian. How could he possibly lead a government that claims to understand, or care for, small business? This legislation has far-reaching and serious consequences for millions of Australians. It needs to be considered carefully. Its what our constituents send us to this place to do. They expect us to speak for them, their families and their communities. I apologise to my constituents that this debate has been rushed. There is more I would like to say but the governments determination to truncate due process and debate has let us all down. By rushing this bill through parliament, this government lets down all Australians.
subdebateinfo: Fair Work Legislation Amendment (Secure Jobs, Better Pay) Bill 2022
Speaker: Mr VIOLI (Casey)

name: Wilson, Rick MP
content: It is getting late. Unfortunately, because of our curtailed time, I only have a few moments to make some very brief comments on this industrial relations legislation—the Fair Work Legislation Amendment (Secure Jobs, Better Pay) Bill 2022—which is simply going to make a bad situation worse. I sat in the chamber and listened to some of the contributions earlier today. The government members roundly condemned the wage system that weve been operating under for the nine years of coalition government. It did occur to me—and its certainly ironic—that, when you think back to the achievements of the Rudd-Gillard-Rudd era, Fair Work Australia was probably one of the few that actually worked somewhere close to the way it might have been planned, when you think about cash for clunkers, the border policies, the mining tax and other issues from the era.The Fair Work Australia legislation has actually served the country pretty well. Unfortunately, because of the decisions of the Fair Work Australia commissioners over the years, real wages havent quite kept up with inflation. That is something that none of us are happy about and none of us enjoy. However I would like to point out to the chamber—and, unfortunately, there are only a couple of government members here—that, during that period, for someone earning a little bit over an average wage of up to $90,000, we delivered tax cuts of up to $3,000. So, while wages didnt necessarily quite keep up with inflation, the previous coalition government certainly made an attempt to make sure that working people took home more of their pay to help pay those bills.The other issue that received a lot of attention was the gender pay gap. I did a bit of research on that. In 2013, when the coalition came into government, the gender pay gap was 17.2 per cent. Today its 14.1 per cent, so thats a number we delivered that Im proud of. It could be better; we all know that. It will be interesting to see where that number is in three years time. Certainly the government have made some big promises in that regard, as they have made some big promises in relation to real wages. Theyll be judged on that in three years time. Thatll be up to the Australian people to judge.But the thing I wanted to talk about tonight is the impact of these changes on small business. Across the electorate of OConnor, I have 21,000 small businesses now. Its a mining electorate, its an agricultural electorate and it has a lot of hospitality and tourism type businesses. The mining companies fly in their workforce, mainly from Perth, but the industry is supported by hundreds of local contractors, some of which are quite big businesses. They employ up to 100 people, some of them even more. The impact of these changes on those businesses is going to be enormous, and, let me tell you, in Western Australia at the moment the reality is that, at 3.1 per cent unemployment, the most valuable asset that any business has, whether it be a farming business, a mining contracting business or a tourism business, is its staff. Everywhere I go, people say, Im doing well because Ive got great staff and Im looking after them and I want to keep them and Ill do whatever I can to keep them. I hear stories of apprentices finishing their apprenticeship at a farm machinery dealership which has looked after them through that apprenticeship, and they can immediately go off and get a job as a fitter on a mine site for $180,000 a year. And theyll do that. That means that those people arent worried about the award wage. Theyre not worried about what Fair Work Australia might say. At 3.1 per cent unemployment in Western Australia, the market sorts these things out, and, if youre not happy with where youre working or with the wage youre getting, or if the boss isnt looking after you, you go and get another job.Going back to 2013, when the coalition came to government, that unemployment number was 5.8 per cent. Thats an oversupply of people looking for work. That means youve got no bargaining power. Under the coalition, with 3.5 per cent unemployment, workers have tremendous bargaining power. They can go out into the marketplace and get the best possible deal for themselves.

name: Wolahan, Keith MP
content: I thank all of the others who have given a contribution on the Fair Work Legislation Amendment (Secure Jobs, Better Pay) Bill 2022 today and through the evening, as many will after me. Im one of the 35 new members of this House, and someone whos no longer in this House told me, Remember, you have two ears and one mouth, so make sure that you learn more than you talk. Ive tried to do that. One thing Ive noticed as a new member is that theres plenty of advice from over there about what lessons were learnt or not learnt from the election. We also see plenty of advice coming from the crossbench, many of whom have taken former Liberal seats, and a lot of that advice is fair and we should learn from it. But sometimes advice can go the other way. Like many others, Ive sat around at dinners chatting to my colleagues about how long we are going to be on this side of the House. Its a question we have. Will it be one term? Two terms? Are we going to be here for a decade? Will I be an older, fatter man by the time I get the privilege to be over there?

name: MemberContinuation
content: Mr WOLAHAN: Thats right! Many have said, in a complimentary way, that it is quite extraordinary and somewhat worrying that the Prime Minister appears to be moving to the Centre. That points to someone who takes that job seriously and does want to be there for a long time.But then this happened. And it reminds me of the old fable of the scorpion and the frog. The scorpion wants to cross a river but cannot swim, so it asks the frog to carry it across. The frog hesitates, afraid the scorpion might sting. The scorpion proposes a bargain. The scorpion promises not to sting, noting it would drown and it would kill both of them. This sounds sensible, so the frog agrees to the bargain. Midway across the river, the scorpion stings anyway, dooming them both. Dying, the frog asks, Why? And the scorpion replies, Im sorry, but I couldnt resist the urge. Its in my nature. In this bill, we get a sense of the nature of your party. You cannot resist the urge. Instead of a frog, its small business. Instead of a river, you asked for permission at an election. Small business, trusting you, thought: How could the Labor Party destroy us? If it does, it wont be sitting on those benches for as long as it thinks. It wont be governing from the centre, like it claimed to. In this bill, we see the Labor Party returning to its nature.I reflect on a Victorian who passed away recently. I hope we will have condolence motions soon. In 1998, a brave man saw that the Australian docks could do more to be competitive. Despite being the conduit for over 70 per cent of the nations imports and exports, its services were more expensive and less reliable than our overseas competitors. In short, the docks were unproductive. They were the gateway for the economy, out and in. This brave man, ably supported by his leader, set out to do the right thing—not the popular thing and not the easy thing. A bitter dispute occurred. We saw all the pictures. I remember as a high school student and then a university student seeing it in the newspapers and on TV. That mans name was Peter Reith. He was a proud Victorian and a proud Liberal. He would be horrified by this bill.He would also be proud of the Liberal Party. He would be proud of its members standing up here—not going home and not taking the easy path—standing up for whats right and standing up for small business. At its heart, thats what he stood up for, and thats why he was a Liberal. The history of industrial relations in this country in these past three decades should read as something more positive; it should read as a growing tale of productivity, of freedom of negotiation and decentralised decision-making. That should be something that a modern, forward-thinking Labor Party should embrace. But, again, they cant help themselves; they cant help the urge to act in their nature.Todays bill unwinds the clock. Todays bill takes us back to the past. I could go through all the problems of this bill. To the credit of some of the crossbench, they have singled out multi-employer bargaining. I think there are many who wont cross that river with the Labor Party.
